docs.lead_paragraph: The number of American military men and women who say they use marijuana, the most prevalent of the illicit drugs, has declined by two-thirds over the last five years. In a confidential Pentagon survey of forces here and abroad, 12 percent of the respondents said they had used marijuana within the preceding 30 days, officials said. That compared with 22 percent in 1982 and 37 percent in 1980 reported by the Pentagon in earlier surveys. In recent interviews, field commanders of the four services also reported that drug abuse among the forces appeared to have declined.

headline.main: SURVEY FINDS SHARP DROP IN MARIJUANA USE IN THE MILITARY, PENTAGON SAYS

byline.original: By RICHARD HALLORAN, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Federally financed medical review agencies have begun disciplinary proceedings against more than 1,100 doctors and hospitals around the nation in the last few months, charging them with providing unnecessary or poor medical treatment. The number of cases has increased dramatically over previous years, according to Federal officials, although comparative numbers were not available. Most of the new cases, whose processing began after the review agencies were reorganized in each state in 1984, are in the early phase. Officials of the program say many cases may be dropped or resolved without formal action.

byline.original: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: JOGGING DOWN A NEW JER-sey park trail one morning, Ed Morgan felt wonderfully content. A tall man of 62, lean and fit, he particularly enjoyed running on such a day; his business, selling insulation supplies, was doing better than ever and his children and grandchildren were all thriving. As always, nearing home he broke into a sprint, but that day, to his surprise, he ended up gasping desperately for air. Alarmed, he went to his doctor and got bad news: an X-ray showed a large tumor on his right lung. A few weeks later, he was operated on. The tumor proved to be a pleural mesothelioma, a type of cancer; the surgeon removed as much as he could. Chemotherapy and radiation would buy Ed Morgan (not his real name) a little time, but the end was predictable.

byline.original: By Morton Hunt: Morton Hunt writes often about the ethical implications of scientific advances

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the psychiatrist Karl Prinzhorn collected and wrote about it in the early 1920's, it was simply called the drawings and paintings of the insane; now it's ''Outsider Art.'' This is for once a euphemism that's called for, and it's not because progress in psychiatry has made insanity hard, if not impossible, to define. And it is especially not because patients today go free, though dependent on drugs, who yesterday were adjudged fit to be tied. The work of the sedated lacks the special quality that would make it Outsider Art -and is to the real thing what mission-school sculpture is to genuine tribal work. Rather, Outsider Art is a useful term because being clinically crazy is not necessarily a prerequisite for genius, although to judge from the recent traveling show of art from the Prinzhorn Collection it certainly helps.

headline.main: ART: THE OUTSIDERS, AT ROSA ESMAN GALLERY

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the Old Testament, Samson's mother is admonished by an angel: ''Thou shalt conceive, and bear a son. Now therefore beware, I pray thee, and drink not wine nor strong drink.'' In ancient Carthage, the law forbade bridal couples to drink on their wedding night. And in 1834, a report to the British House of Commons noted that infants born to alcoholic mothers had ''a starved, shriveled and imperfect look.'' But it was not until 1973 that medical scientists confirmed what people seem to have known for thousands of years: that alcohol consumed by a pregnant woman can damage her unborn child. That year two pediatric researchers from the University of Washington in Seattle rediscovered and named fetal alcohol syndrome. At first it was thought that only the offspring of heavy-drinking alcoholic mothers were at risk. Now it is known that even as little as two drinks a week may do damage, and knowledgeable physicians recommend that women abstain completely from alcohol from the moment they start trying to conceive until they are finished nursing. Even women who drank during previous pregnancies with no apparent ill effect on their offspring are cautioned against assuming that subsequent children will be similarly spared.

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from Governor Cuomo's budget message to the State Legislature: Within its pages, this budget will propose many opportunities for combining the energies and goals of the state, local governments, the private sector and all New Yorkers, so that the total of our efforts will be stronger and more lasting than could be achieved by any one institution alone. This 1986-87 budget is a tax-cut budget. It cuts taxes some $1 billion. This 1986-87 tax cut continues the progress we began last year with our multiyear plan to revitalize the economy of New York. It also offers our unemployed youth and those dependent on public assistance new and effective ways to find entry into the private work force. It provides our frail elderly, and those too vulnerable or disabled to work, with ways to enjoy the quality of life that others of us are fortunate enough to take for granted. It provides our program managers the tools to exercise their best professional abilities and to improve the administration of their operations. And it gives us all a chance to remove the hazardous toxic substances that have poisoned our enviroment.

headline.main: EXCERPTS FROM CUOMO'S BUDGET MESSAGE TO THE LEGISLATURE
headline.kicker: THE CUOMO BUDGET: MIXING TAX CUTS WITH HELP FOR THE JOBLESS
